column1: O that you were your self, but love you are
column2: No longer yours, than you your self here live,
column3: Against this coming end you should prepare,
column4: And your sweet semblance to some other give.
column5: So should that beauty which you hold in lease
column6: Find no determination, then you were
column7: Your self again after your self's decease,
column8: When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.
column9: Who lets so fair a house fall to decay,
column10: Which husbandry in honour might uphold,
column11: Against the stormy gusts of winter's day
column12: And barren rage of death's eternal cold?
column13: O none but unthrifts, dear my love you know,
column14: You had a father, let your son say so.

column1: But wherefore do not you a mightier way
column2: Make war upon this bloody tyrant Time?
column3: And fortify your self in your decay
column4: With means more blessed than my barren rhyme?
column5: Now stand you on the top of happy hours,
column6: And many maiden gardens yet unset,
column7: With virtuous wish would bear you living flowers,
column8: Much liker than your painted counterfeit:
column9: So should the lines of life that life repair
column10: Which this (Time's pencil) or my pupil pen
column11: Neither in inward worth nor outward fair
column12: Can make you live your self in eyes of men.
column13: To give away your self, keeps your self still,
column14: And you must live drawn by your own sweet skill.

column1: Who will believe my verse in time to come
column2: If it were filled with your most high deserts?
column3: Though yet heaven knows it is but as a tomb
column4: Which hides your life, and shows not half your parts:
column5: If I could write the beauty of your eyes,
column6: And in fresh numbers number all your graces,
column7: The age to come would say this poet lies,
column8: Such heavenly touches ne'er touched earthly faces.
column9: So should my papers (yellowed with their age)
column10: Be scorned, like old men of less truth than tongue,
column11: And your true rights be termed a poet's rage,
column12: And stretched metre of an antique song.
column13: But were some child of yours alive that time,
column14: You should live twice in it, and in my rhyme.

column1: A woman's face with nature's own hand painted,
column2: Hast thou the master mistress of my passion,
column3: A woman's gentle heart but not acquainted
column4: With shifting change as is false women's fashion,
column5: An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling:
column6: Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth,
column7: A man in hue all hues in his controlling,
column8: Which steals men's eyes and women's souls amazeth.
column9: And for a woman wert thou first created,
column10: Till nature as she wrought thee fell a-doting,
column11: And by addition me of thee defeated,
column12: By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.
column13: But since she pricked thee out for women's pleasure,
column14: Mine be thy love and thy love's use their treasure.

column1: So is it not with me as with that muse,
column2: Stirred by a painted beauty to his verse,
column3: Who heaven it self for ornament doth use,
column4: And every fair with his fair doth rehearse,
column5: Making a couplement of proud compare
column6: With sun and moon, with earth and sea's rich gems:
column7: With April's first-born flowers and all things rare,
column8: That heaven's air in this huge rondure hems.
column9: O let me true in love but truly write,
column10: And then believe me, my love is as fair,
column11: As any mother's child, though not so bright
column12: As those gold candles fixed in heaven's air:
column13: Let them say more that like of hearsay well,
column14: I will not praise that purpose not to sell.

column1: Thy bosom is endeared with all hearts,
column2: Which I by lacking have supposed dead,
column3: And there reigns love and all love's loving parts,
column4: And all those friends which I thought buried.
column5: How many a holy and obsequious tear
column6: Hath dear religious love stol'n from mine eye,
column7: As interest of the dead, which now appear,
column8: But things removed that hidden in thee lie.
column9: Thou art the grave where buried love doth live,
column10: Hung with the trophies of my lovers gone,
column11: Who all their parts of me to thee did give,
column12: That due of many, now is thine alone.
column13: Their images I loved, I view in thee,
column14: And thou (all they) hast all the all of me.

column1: Let me confess that we two must be twain,
column2: Although our undivided loves are one:
column3: So shall those blots that do with me remain,
column4: Without thy help, by me be borne alone.
column5: In our two loves there is but one respect,
column6: Though in our lives a separable spite,
column7: Which though it alter not love's sole effect,
column8: Yet doth it steal sweet hours from love's delight.
column9: I may not evermore acknowledge thee,
column10: Lest my bewailed guilt should do thee shame,
column11: Nor thou with public kindness honour me,
column12: Unless thou take that honour from thy name:
column13: But do not so, I love thee in such sort,
column14: As thou being mine, mine is thy good report.

column1: As a decrepit father takes delight,
column2: To see his active child do deeds of youth,
column3: So I, made lame by Fortune's dearest spite
column4: Take all my comfort of thy worth and truth.
column5: For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit,
column6: Or any of these all, or all, or more
column7: Entitled in thy parts, do crowned sit,
column8: I make my love engrafted to this store:
column9: So then I am not lame, poor, nor despised,
column10: Whilst that this shadow doth such substance give,
column11: That I in thy abundance am sufficed,
column12: And by a part of all thy glory live:
column13: Look what is best, that best I wish in thee,
column14: This wish I have, then ten times happy me.

column1: That thou hast her it is not all my grief,
column2: And yet it may be said I loved her dearly,
column3: That she hath thee is of my wailing chief,
column4: A loss in love that touches me more nearly.
column5: Loving offenders thus I will excuse ye,
column6: Thou dost love her, because thou know'st I love her,
column7: And for my sake even so doth she abuse me,
column8: Suff'ring my friend for my sake to approve her.
column9: If I lose thee, my loss is my love's gain,
column10: And losing her, my friend hath found that loss,
column11: Both find each other, and I lose both twain,
column12: And both for my sake lay on me this cross,
column13: But here's the joy, my friend and I are one,
column14: Sweet flattery, then she loves but me alone.

column1: If the dull substance of my flesh were thought,
column2: Injurious distance should not stop my way,
column3: For then despite of space I would be brought,
column4: From limits far remote, where thou dost stay,
column5: No matter then although my foot did stand
column6: Upon the farthest earth removed from thee,
column7: For nimble thought can jump both sea and land,
column8: As soon as think the place where he would be.
column9: But ah, thought kills me that I am not thought
column10: To leap large lengths of miles when thou art gone,
column11: But that so much of earth and water wrought,
column12: I must attend, time's leisure with my moan.
column13: Receiving nought by elements so slow,
column14: But heavy tears, badges of either's woe.

column1: The other two, slight air, and purging fire,
column2: Are both with thee, wherever I abide,
column3: The first my thought, the other my desire,
column4: These present-absent with swift motion slide.
column5: For when these quicker elements are gone
column6: In tender embassy of love to thee,
column7: My life being made of four, with two alone,
column8: Sinks down to death, oppressed with melancholy.
column9: Until life's composition be recured,
column10: By those swift messengers returned from thee,
column11: Who even but now come back again assured,
column12: Of thy fair health, recounting it to me.
column13: This told, I joy, but then no longer glad,
column14: I send them back again and straight grow sad.

column1: Mine eye and heart are at a mortal war,
column2: How to divide the conquest of thy sight,
column3: Mine eye, my heart thy picture's sight would bar,
column4: My heart, mine eye the freedom of that right,
column5: My heart doth plead that thou in him dost lie,
column6: (A closet never pierced with crystal eyes)
column7: But the defendant doth that plea deny,
column8: And says in him thy fair appearance lies.
column9: To side this title is impanelled
column10: A quest of thoughts, all tenants to the heart,
column11: And by their verdict is determined
column12: The clear eye's moiety, and the dear heart's part.
column13: As thus, mine eye's due is thy outward part,
column14: And my heart's right, thy inward love of heart.

column1: Betwixt mine eye and heart a league is took,
column2: And each doth good turns now unto the other,
column3: When that mine eye is famished for a look,
column4: Or heart in love with sighs himself doth smother;
column5: With my love's picture then my eye doth feast,
column6: And to the painted banquet bids my heart:
column7: Another time mine eye is my heart's guest,
column8: And in his thoughts of love doth share a part.
column9: So either by thy picture or my love,
column10: Thy self away, art present still with me,
column11: For thou not farther than my thoughts canst move,
column12: And I am still with them, and they with thee.
column13: Or if they sleep, thy picture in my sight
column14: Awakes my heart, to heart's and eye's delight.

column1: Against that time (if ever that time come)
column2: When I shall see thee frown on my defects,
column3: When as thy love hath cast his utmost sum,
column4: Called to that audit by advised respects,
column5: Against that time when thou shalt strangely pass,
column6: And scarcely greet me with that sun thine eye,
column7: When love converted from the thing it was
column8: Shall reasons find of settled gravity;
column9: Against that time do I ensconce me here
column10: Within the knowledge of mine own desert,
column11: And this my hand, against my self uprear,
column12: To guard the lawful reasons on thy part,
column13: To leave poor me, thou hast the strength of laws,
column14: Since why to love, I can allege no cause.

column1: So am I as the rich whose blessed key,
column2: Can bring him to his sweet up-locked treasure,
column3: The which he will not every hour survey,
column4: For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.
column5: Therefore are feasts so solemn and so rare,
column6: Since seldom coming in that long year set,
column7: Like stones of worth they thinly placed are,
column8: Or captain jewels in the carcanet.
column9: So is the time that keeps you as my chest
column10: Or as the wardrobe which the robe doth hide,
column11: To make some special instant special-blest,
column12: By new unfolding his imprisoned pride.
column13: Blessed are you whose worthiness gives scope,
column14: Being had to triumph, being lacked to hope.

column1: What is your substance, whereof are you made,
column2: That millions of strange shadows on you tend?
column3: Since every one, hath every one, one shade,
column4: And you but one, can every shadow lend:
column5: Describe Adonis and the counterfeit,
column6: Is poorly imitated after you,
column7: On Helen's cheek all art of beauty set,
column8: And you in Grecian tires are painted new:
column9: Speak of the spring, and foison of the year,
column10: The one doth shadow of your beauty show,
column11: The other as your bounty doth appear,
column12: And you in every blessed shape we know.
column13: In all external grace you have some part,
column14: But you like none, none you for constant heart.

column1: Sweet love renew thy force, be it not said
column2: Thy edge should blunter be than appetite,
column3: Which but to-day by feeding is allayed,
column4: To-morrow sharpened in his former might.
column5: So love be thou, although to-day thou fill
column6: Thy hungry eyes, even till they wink with fulness,
column7: To-morrow see again, and do not kill
column8: The spirit of love, with a perpetual dulness:
column9: Let this sad interim like the ocean be
column10: Which parts the shore, where two contracted new,
column11: Come daily to the banks, that when they see:
column12: Return of love, more blest may be the view.
column13: Or call it winter, which being full of care,
column14: Makes summer's welcome, thrice more wished, more rare.

column1: Being your slave what should I do but tend,
column2: Upon the hours, and times of your desire?
column3: I have no precious time at all to spend;
column4: Nor services to do till you require.
column5: Nor dare I chide the world-without-end hour,
column6: Whilst I (my sovereign) watch the clock for you,
column7: Nor think the bitterness of absence sour,
column8: When you have bid your servant once adieu.
column9: Nor dare I question with my jealous thought,
column10: Where you may be, or your affairs suppose,
column11: But like a sad slave stay and think of nought
column12: Save where you are, how happy you make those.
column13: So true a fool is love, that in your will,
column14: (Though you do any thing) he thinks no ill.

column1: If there be nothing new, but that which is,
column2: Hath been before, how are our brains beguiled,
column3: Which labouring for invention bear amis
column4: The second burthen of a former child!
column5: O that record could with a backward look,
column6: Even of five hundred courses of the sun,
column7: Show me your image in some antique book,
column8: Since mind at first in character was done.
column9: That I might see what the old world could say,
column10: To this composed wonder of your frame,
column11: Whether we are mended, or whether better they,
column12: Or whether revolution be the same.
column13: O sure I am the wits of former days,
column14: To subjects worse have given admiring praise.

column1: Is it thy will, thy image should keep open
column2: My heavy eyelids to the weary night?
column3: Dost thou desire my slumbers should be broken,
column4: While shadows like to thee do mock my sight?
column5: Is it thy spirit that thou send'st from thee
column6: So far from home into my deeds to pry,
column7: To find out shames and idle hours in me,
column8: The scope and tenure of thy jealousy?
column9: O no, thy love though much, is not so great,
column10: It is my love that keeps mine eye awake,
column11: Mine own true love that doth my rest defeat,
column12: To play the watchman ever for thy sake.
column13: For thee watch I, whilst thou dost wake elsewhere,
column14: From me far off, with others all too near.

column1: When I have seen by Time's fell hand defaced
column2: The rich-proud cost of outworn buried age,
column3: When sometime lofty towers I see down-rased,
column4: And brass eternal slave to mortal rage.
column5: When I have seen the hungry ocean gain
column6: Advantage on the kingdom of the shore,
column7: And the firm soil win of the watery main,
column8: Increasing store with loss, and loss with store.
column9: When I have seen such interchange of State,
column10: Or state it self confounded, to decay,
column11: Ruin hath taught me thus to ruminate
column12: That Time will come and take my love away.
column13: This thought is as a death which cannot choose
column14: But weep to have, that which it fears to lose.

column1: Ah wherefore with infection should he live,
column2: And with his presence grace impiety,
column3: That sin by him advantage should achieve,
column4: And lace it self with his society?
column5: Why should false painting imitate his cheek,
column6: And steal dead seeming of his living hue?
column7: Why should poor beauty indirectly seek,
column8: Roses of shadow, since his rose is true?
column9: Why should he live, now nature bankrupt is,
column10: Beggared of blood to blush through lively veins,
column11: For she hath no exchequer now but his,
column12: And proud of many, lives upon his gains?
column13: O him she stores, to show what wealth she had,
column14: In days long since, before these last so bad.

column1: Those parts of thee that the world's eye doth view,
column2: Want nothing that the thought of hearts can mend:
column3: All tongues (the voice of souls) give thee that due,
column4: Uttering bare truth, even so as foes commend.
column5: Thy outward thus with outward praise is crowned,
column6: But those same tongues that give thee so thine own,
column7: In other accents do this praise confound
column8: By seeing farther than the eye hath shown.
column9: They look into the beauty of thy mind,
column10: And that in guess they measure by thy deeds,
column11: Then churls their thoughts (although their eyes were kind)
column12: To thy fair flower add the rank smell of weeds:
column13: But why thy odour matcheth not thy show,
column14: The soil is this, that thou dost common grow.

column1: No longer mourn for me when I am dead,
column2: Than you shall hear the surly sullen bell
column3: Give warning to the world that I am fled
column4: From this vile world with vilest worms to dwell:
column5: Nay if you read this line, remember not,
column6: The hand that writ it, for I love you so,
column7: That I in your sweet thoughts would be forgot,
column8: If thinking on me then should make you woe.
column9: O if (I say) you look upon this verse,
column10: When I (perhaps) compounded am with clay,
column11: Do not so much as my poor name rehearse;
column12: But let your love even with my life decay.
column13: Lest the wise world should look into your moan,
column14: And mock you with me after I am gone.

column1: O lest the world should task you to recite,
column2: What merit lived in me that you should love
column3: After my death (dear love) forget me quite,
column4: For you in me can nothing worthy prove.
column5: Unless you would devise some virtuous lie,
column6: To do more for me than mine own desert,
column7: And hang more praise upon deceased I,
column8: Than niggard truth would willingly impart:
column9: O lest your true love may seem false in this,
column10: That you for love speak well of me untrue,
column11: My name be buried where my body is,
column12: And live no more to shame nor me, nor you.
column13: For I am shamed by that which I bring forth,
column14: And so should you, to love things nothing worth.

column1: But be contented when that fell arrest,
column2: Without all bail shall carry me away,
column3: My life hath in this line some interest,
column4: Which for memorial still with thee shall stay.
column5: When thou reviewest this, thou dost review,
column6: The very part was consecrate to thee,
column7: The earth can have but earth, which is his due,
column8: My spirit is thine the better part of me,
column9: So then thou hast but lost the dregs of life,
column10: The prey of worms, my body being dead,
column11: The coward conquest of a wretch's knife,
column12: Too base of thee to be remembered,
column13: The worth of that, is that which it contains,
column14: And that is this, and this with thee remains.

column1: Why is my verse so barren of new pride?
column2: So far from variation or quick change?
column3: Why with the time do I not glance aside
column4: To new-found methods, and to compounds strange?
column5: Why write I still all one, ever the same,
column6: And keep invention in a noted weed,
column7: That every word doth almost tell my name,
column8: Showing their birth, and where they did proceed?
column9: O know sweet love I always write of you,
column10: And you and love are still my argument:
column11: So all my best is dressing old words new,
column12: Spending again what is already spent:
column13: For as the sun is daily new and old,
column14: So is my love still telling what is told.

column1: So oft have I invoked thee for my muse,
column2: And found such fair assistance in my verse,
column3: As every alien pen hath got my use,
column4: And under thee their poesy disperse.
column5: Thine eyes, that taught the dumb on high to sing,
column6: And heavy ignorance aloft to fly,
column7: Have added feathers to the learned's wing,
column8: And given grace a double majesty.
column9: Yet be most proud of that which I compile,
column10: Whose influence is thine, and born of thee,
column11: In others' works thou dost but mend the style,
column12: And arts with thy sweet graces graced be.
column13: But thou art all my art, and dost advance
column14: As high as learning, my rude ignorance.

column1: Whilst I alone did call upon thy aid,
column2: My verse alone had all thy gentle grace,
column3: But now my gracious numbers are decayed,
column4: And my sick muse doth give an other place.
column5: I grant (sweet love) thy lovely argument
column6: Deserves the travail of a worthier pen,
column7: Yet what of thee thy poet doth invent,
column8: He robs thee of, and pays it thee again,
column9: He lends thee virtue, and he stole that word,
column10: From thy behaviour, beauty doth he give
column11: And found it in thy cheek: he can afford
column12: No praise to thee, but what in thee doth live.
column13: Then thank him not for that which he doth say,
column14: Since what he owes thee, thou thy self dost pay.

column1: O how I faint when I of you do write,
column2: Knowing a better spirit doth use your name,
column3: And in the praise thereof spends all his might,
column4: To make me tongue-tied speaking of your fame.
column5: But since your worth (wide as the ocean is)
column6: The humble as the proudest sail doth bear,
column7: My saucy bark (inferior far to his)
column8: On your broad main doth wilfully appear.
column9: Your shallowest help will hold me up afloat,
column10: Whilst he upon your soundless deep doth ride,
column11: Or (being wrecked) I am a worthless boat,
column12: He of tall building, and of goodly pride.
column13: Then if he thrive and I be cast away,
column14: The worst was this, my love was my decay.

column1: Or I shall live your epitaph to make,
column2: Or you survive when I in earth am rotten,
column3: From hence your memory death cannot take,
column4: Although in me each part will be forgotten.
column5: Your name from hence immortal life shall have,
column6: Though I (once gone) to all the world must die,
column7: The earth can yield me but a common grave,
column8: When you entombed in men's eyes shall lie,
column9: Your monument shall be my gentle verse,
column10: Which eyes not yet created shall o'er-read,
column11: And tongues to be, your being shall rehearse,
column12: When all the breathers of this world are dead,
column13: You still shall live (such virtue hath my pen)
column14: Where breath most breathes, even in the mouths of men.

column1: I never saw that you did painting need,
column2: And therefore to your fair no painting set,
column3: I found (or thought I found) you did exceed,
column4: That barren tender of a poet's debt:
column5: And therefore have I slept in your report,
column6: That you your self being extant well might show,
column7: How far a modern quill doth come too short,
column8: Speaking of worth, what worth in you doth grow.
column9: This silence for my sin you did impute,
column10: Which shall be most my glory being dumb,
column11: For I impair not beauty being mute,
column12: When others would give life, and bring a tomb.
column13: There lives more life in one of your fair eyes,
column14: Than both your poets can in praise devise.

column1: My tongue-tied muse in manners holds her still,
column2: While comments of your praise richly compiled,
column3: Reserve their character with golden quill,
column4: And precious phrase by all the Muses filed.
column5: I think good thoughts, whilst other write good words,
column6: And like unlettered clerk still cry Amen,
column7: To every hymn that able spirit affords,
column8: In polished form of well refined pen.
column9: Hearing you praised, I say 'tis so, 'tis true,
column10: And to the most of praise add something more,
column11: But that is in my thought, whose love to you
column12: (Though words come hindmost) holds his rank before,
column13: Then others, for the breath of words respect,
column14: Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.

column1: Was it the proud full sail of his great verse,
column2: Bound for the prize of (all too precious) you,
column3: That did my ripe thoughts in my brain inhearse,
column4: Making their tomb the womb wherein they grew?
column5: Was it his spirit, by spirits taught to write,
column6: Above a mortal pitch, that struck me dead?
column7: No, neither he, nor his compeers by night
column8: Giving him aid, my verse astonished.
column9: He nor that affable familiar ghost
column10: Which nightly gulls him with intelligence,
column11: As victors of my silence cannot boast,
column12: I was not sick of any fear from thence.
column13: But when your countenance filled up his line,
column14: Then lacked I matter, that enfeebled mine.

column1: When thou shalt be disposed to set me light,
column2: And place my merit in the eye of scorn,
column3: Upon thy side, against my self I'll fight,
column4: And prove thee virtuous, though thou art forsworn:
column5: With mine own weakness being best acquainted,
column6: Upon thy part I can set down a story
column7: Of faults concealed, wherein I am attainted:
column8: That thou in losing me, shalt win much glory:
column9: And I by this will be a gainer too,
column10: For bending all my loving thoughts on thee,
column11: The injuries that to my self I do,
column12: Doing thee vantage, double-vantage me.
column13: Such is my love, to thee I so belong,
column14: That for thy right, my self will bear all wrong.

column1: Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
column2: Some in their wealth, some in their body's force,
column3: Some in their garments though new-fangled ill:
column4: Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse.
column5: And every humour hath his adjunct pleasure,
column6: Wherein it finds a joy above the rest,
column7: But these particulars are not my measure,
column8: All these I better in one general best.
column9: Thy love is better than high birth to me,
column10: Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' costs,
column11: Of more delight than hawks and horses be:
column12: And having thee, of all men's pride I boast.
column13: Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take,
column14: All this away, and me most wretched make.

column1: How sweet and lovely dost thou make the shame,
column2: Which like a canker in the fragrant rose,
column3: Doth spot the beauty of thy budding name!
column4: O in what sweets dost thou thy sins enclose!
column5: That tongue that tells the story of thy days,
column6: (Making lascivious comments on thy sport)
column7: Cannot dispraise, but in a kind of praise,
column8: Naming thy name, blesses an ill report.
column9: O what a mansion have those vices got,
column10: Which for their habitation chose out thee,
column11: Where beauty's veil doth cover every blot,
column12: And all things turns to fair, that eyes can see!
column13: Take heed (dear heart) of this large privilege,
column14: The hardest knife ill-used doth lose his edge.

column1: From you have I been absent in the spring,
column2: When proud-pied April (dressed in all his trim)
column3: Hath put a spirit of youth in every thing:
column4: That heavy Saturn laughed and leaped with him.
column5: Yet nor the lays of birds, nor the sweet smell
column6: Of different flowers in odour and in hue,
column7: Could make me any summer's story tell:
column8: Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew:
column9: Nor did I wonder at the lily's white,
column10: Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose,
column11: They were but sweet, but figures of delight:
column12: Drawn after you, you pattern of all those.
column13: Yet seemed it winter still, and you away,
column14: As with your shadow I with these did play.

column1: Alack what poverty my muse brings forth,
column2: That having such a scope to show her pride,
column3: The argument all bare is of more worth
column4: Than when it hath my added praise beside.
column5: O blame me not if I no more can write!
column6: Look in your glass and there appears a face,
column7: That over-goes my blunt invention quite,
column8: Dulling my lines, and doing me disgrace.
column9: Were it not sinful then striving to mend,
column10: To mar the subject that before was well?
column11: For to no other pass my verses tend,
column12: Than of your graces and your gifts to tell.
column13: And more, much more than in my verse can sit,
column14: Your own glass shows you, when you look in it.

column1: Let not my love be called idolatry,
column2: Nor my beloved as an idol show,
column3: Since all alike my songs and praises be
column4: To one, of one, still such, and ever so.
column5: Kind is my love to-day, to-morrow kind,
column6: Still constant in a wondrous excellence,
column7: Therefore my verse to constancy confined,
column8: One thing expressing, leaves out difference.
column9: Fair, kind, and true, is all my argument,
column10: Fair, kind, and true, varying to other words,
column11: And in this change is my invention spent,
column12: Three themes in one, which wondrous scope affords.
column13: Fair, kind, and true, have often lived alone.
column14: Which three till now, never kept seat in one.

column1: What's in the brain that ink may character,
column2: Which hath not figured to thee my true spirit,
column3: What's new to speak, what now to register,
column4: That may express my love, or thy dear merit?
column5: Nothing sweet boy, but yet like prayers divine,
column6: I must each day say o'er the very same,
column7: Counting no old thing old, thou mine, I thine,
column8: Even as when first I hallowed thy fair name.
column9: So that eternal love in love's fresh case,
column10: Weighs not the dust and injury of age,
column11: Nor gives to necessary wrinkles place,
column12: But makes antiquity for aye his page,
column13: Finding the first conceit of love there bred,
column14: Where time and outward form would show it dead.

column1: O never say that I was false of heart,
column2: Though absence seemed my flame to qualify,
column3: As easy might I from my self depart,
column4: As from my soul which in thy breast doth lie:
column5: That is my home of love, if I have ranged,
column6: Like him that travels I return again,
column7: Just to the time, not with the time exchanged,
column8: So that my self bring water for my stain,
column9: Never believe though in my nature reigned,
column10: All frailties that besiege all kinds of blood,
column11: That it could so preposterously be stained,
column12: To leave for nothing all thy sum of good:
column13: For nothing this wide universe I call,
column14: Save thou my rose, in it thou art my all.

column1: Alas 'tis true, I have gone here and there,
column2: And made my self a motley to the view,
column3: Gored mine own thoughts, sold cheap what is most dear,
column4: Made old offences of affections new.
column5: Most true it is, that I have looked on truth
column6: Askance and strangely: but by all above,
column7: These blenches gave my heart another youth,
column8: And worse essays proved thee my best of love.
column9: Now all is done, have what shall have no end,
column10: Mine appetite I never more will grind
column11: On newer proof, to try an older friend,
column12: A god in love, to whom I am confined.
column13: Then give me welcome, next my heaven the best,
column14: Even to thy pure and most most loving breast.

column1: O for my sake do you with Fortune chide,
column2: The guilty goddess of my harmful deeds,
column3: That did not better for my life provide,
column4: Than public means which public manners breeds.
column5: Thence comes it that my name receives a brand,
column6: And almost thence my nature is subdued
column7: To what it works in, like the dyer's hand:
column8: Pity me then, and wish I were renewed,
column9: Whilst like a willing patient I will drink,
column10: Potions of eisel 'gainst my strong infection,
column11: No bitterness that I will bitter think,
column12: Nor double penance to correct correction.
column13: Pity me then dear friend, and I assure ye,
column14: Even that your pity is enough to cure me.

column1: Like as to make our appetite more keen
column2: With eager compounds we our palate urge,
column3: As to prevent our maladies unseen,
column4: We sicken to shun sickness when we purge.
column5: Even so being full of your ne'er-cloying sweetness,
column6: To bitter sauces did I frame my feeding;
column7: And sick of welfare found a kind of meetness,
column8: To be diseased ere that there was true needing.
column9: Thus policy in love t' anticipate
column10: The ills that were not, grew to faults assured,
column11: And brought to medicine a healthful state
column12: Which rank of goodness would by ill be cured.
column13: But thence I learn and find the lesson true,
column14: Drugs poison him that so feil sick of you.

column1: What potions have I drunk of Siren tears
column2: Distilled from limbecks foul as hell within,
column3: Applying fears to hopes, and hopes to fears,
column4: Still losing when I saw my self to win!
column5: What wretched errors hath my heart committed,
column6: Whilst it hath thought it self so blessed never!
column7: How have mine eyes out of their spheres been fitted
column8: In the distraction of this madding fever!
column9: O benefit of ill, now I find true
column10: That better is, by evil still made better.
column11: And ruined love when it is built anew
column12: Grows fairer than at first, more strong, far greater.
column13: So I return rebuked to my content,
column14: And gain by ills thrice more than I have spent.

column1: Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain
column2: Full charactered with lasting memory,
column3: Which shall above that idle rank remain
column4: Beyond all date even to eternity.
column5: Or at the least, so long as brain and heart
column6: Have faculty by nature to subsist,
column7: Till each to razed oblivion yield his part
column8: Of thee, thy record never can be missed:
column9: That poor retention could not so much hold,
column10: Nor need I tallies thy dear love to score,
column11: Therefore to give them from me was I bold,
column12: To trust those tables that receive thee more:
column13: To keep an adjunct to remember thee
column14: Were to import forgetfulness in me.

column1: No! Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change,
column2: Thy pyramids built up with newer might
column3: To me are nothing novel, nothing strange,
column4: They are but dressings Of a former sight:
column5: Our dates are brief, and therefore we admire,
column6: What thou dost foist upon us that is old,
column7: And rather make them born to our desire,
column8: Than think that we before have heard them told:
column9: Thy registers and thee I both defy,
column10: Not wond'ring at the present, nor the past,
column11: For thy records, and what we see doth lie,
column12: Made more or less by thy continual haste:
column13: This I do vow and this shall ever be,
column14: I will be true despite thy scythe and thee.

column1: Th' expense of spirit in a waste of shame
column2: Is lust in action, and till action, lust
column3: Is perjured, murd'rous, bloody full of blame,
column4: Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust,
column5: Enjoyed no sooner but despised straight,
column6: Past reason hunted, and no sooner had
column7: Past reason hated as a swallowed bait,
column8: On purpose laid to make the taker mad.
column9: Mad in pursuit and in possession so,
column10: Had, having, and in quest, to have extreme,
column11: A bliss in proof and proved, a very woe,
column12: Before a joy proposed behind a dream.
column13: All this the world well knows yet none knows well,
column14: To shun the heaven that leads men to this hell.

column1: My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun,
column2: Coral is far more red, than her lips red,
column3: If snow be white, why then her breasts are dun:
column4: If hairs be wires, black wires grow on her head:
column5: I have seen roses damasked, red and white,
column6: But no such roses see I in her cheeks,
column7: And in some perfumes is there more delight,
column8: Than in the breath that from my mistress reeks.
column9: I love to hear her speak, yet well I know,
column10: That music hath a far more pleasing sound:
column11: I grant I never saw a goddess go,
column12: My mistress when she walks treads on the ground.
column13: And yet by heaven I think my love as rare,
column14: As any she belied with false compare.

column1: Thine eyes I love, and they as pitying me,
column2: Knowing thy heart torment me with disdain,
column3: Have put on black, and loving mourners be,
column4: Looking with pretty ruth upon my pain.
column5: And truly not the morning sun of heaven
column6: Better becomes the grey cheeks of the east,
column7: Nor that full star that ushers in the even
column8: Doth half that glory to the sober west
column9: As those two mourning eyes become thy face:
column10: O let it then as well beseem thy heart
column11: To mourn for me since mourning doth thee grace,
column12: And suit thy pity like in every part.
column13: Then will I swear beauty herself is black,
column14: And all they foul that thy complexion lack.

column1: Thou blind fool Love, what dost thou to mine eyes,
column2: That they behold and see not what they see?
column3: They know what beauty is, see where it lies,
column4: Yet what the best is, take the worst to be.
column5: If eyes corrupt by over-partial looks,
column6: Be anchored in the bay where all men ride,
column7: Why of eyes' falsehood hast thou forged hooks,
column8: Whereto the judgment of my heart is tied?
column9: Why should my heart think that a several plot,
column10: Which my heart knows the wide world's common place?
column11: Or mine eyes seeing this, say this is not
column12: To put fair truth upon so foul a face?
column13: In things right true my heart and eyes have erred,
column14: And to this false plague are they now transferred.

column1: When my love swears that she is made of truth,
column2: I do believe her though I know she lies,
column3: That she might think me some untutored youth,
column4: Unlearned in the world's false subtleties.
column5: Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young,
column6: Although she knows my days are past the best,
column7: Simply I credit her false-speaking tongue,
column8: On both sides thus is simple truth suppressed:
column9: But wherefore says she not she is unjust?
column10: And wherefore say not I that I am old?
column11: O love's best habit is in seeming trust,
column12: And age in love, loves not to have years told.
column13: Therefore I lie with her, and she with me,
column14: And in our faults by lies we flattered be.

column1: Be wise as thou art cruel, do not press
column2: My tongue-tied patience with too much disdain:
column3: Lest sorrow lend me words and words express,
column4: The manner of my pity-wanting pain.
column5: If I might teach thee wit better it were,
column6: Though not to love, yet love to tell me so,
column7: As testy sick men when their deaths be near,
column8: No news but health from their physicians know.
column9: For if I should despair I should grow mad,
column10: And in my madness might speak ill of thee,
column11: Now this ill-wresting world is grown so bad,
column12: Mad slanderers by mad ears believed be.
column13: That I may not be so, nor thou belied,
column14: Bear thine eyes straight, though thy proud heart go wide.

column1: In faith I do not love thee with mine eyes,
column2: For they in thee a thousand errors note,
column3: But 'tis my heart that loves what they despise,
column4: Who in despite of view is pleased to dote.
column5: Nor are mine cars with thy tongue's tune delighted,
column6: Nor tender feeling to base touches prone,
column7: Nor taste, nor smell, desire to be invited
column8: To any sensual feast with thee alone:
column9: But my five wits, nor my five senses can
column10: Dissuade one foolish heart from serving thee,
column11: Who leaves unswayed the likeness of a man,
column12: Thy proud heart's slave and vassal wretch to be:
column13: Only my plague thus far I count my gain,
column14: That she that makes me sin, awards me pain.

column1: Two loves I have of comfort and despair,
column2: Which like two spirits do suggest me still,
column3: The better angel is a man right fair:
column4: The worser spirit a woman coloured ill.
column5: To win me soon to hell my female evil,
column6: Tempteth my better angel from my side,
column7: And would corrupt my saint to be a devil:
column8: Wooing his purity with her foul pride.
column9: And whether that my angel be turned fiend,
column10: Suspect I may, yet not directly tell,
column11: But being both from me both to each friend,
column12: I guess one angel in another's hell.
column13: Yet this shall I ne'er know but live in doubt,
column14: Till my bad angel fire my good one out.

column1: Poor soul the centre of my sinful earth,
column2: My sinful earth these rebel powers array,
column3: Why dost thou pine within and suffer dearth
column4: Painting thy outward walls so costly gay?
column5: Why so large cost having so short a lease,
column6: Dost thou upon thy fading mansion spend?
column7: Shall worms inheritors of this excess
column8: Eat up thy charge? is this thy body's end?
column9: Then soul live thou upon thy servant's loss,
column10: And let that pine to aggravate thy store;
column11: Buy terms divine in selling hours of dross;
column12: Within be fed, without be rich no more,
column13: So shall thou feed on death, that feeds on men,
column14: And death once dead, there's no more dying then.

column1: Love is too young to know what conscience is,
column2: Yet who knows not conscience is born of love?
column3: Then gentle cheater urge not my amiss,
column4: Lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove.
column5: For thou betraying me, I do betray
column6: My nobler part to my gross body's treason,
column7: My soul doth tell my body that he may,
column8: Triumph in love, flesh stays no farther reason,
column9: But rising at thy name doth point out thee,
column10: As his triumphant prize, proud of this pride,
column11: He is contented thy poor drudge to be,
column12: To stand in thy affairs, fall by thy side.
column13: No want of conscience hold it that I call,
column14: Her love, for whose dear love I rise and fall.

column1: In loving thee thou know'st I am forsworn,
column2: But thou art twice forsworn to me love swearing,
column3: In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn,
column4: In vowing new hate after new love bearing:
column5: But why of two oaths' breach do I accuse thee,
column6: When I break twenty? I am perjured most,
column7: For all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee:
column8: And all my honest faith in thee is lost.
column9: For I have sworn deep oaths of thy deep kindness:
column10: Oaths of thy love, thy truth, thy constancy,
column11: And to enlighten thee gave eyes to blindness,
column12: Or made them swear against the thing they see.
column13: For I have sworn thee fair: more perjured I,
column14: To swear against the truth so foul a be.
